page.title: 02Development of the Village
page.content: Originally the village was situated at Sarclet. The people earned their living by fishing and crofting. By 1906 only a Post Office,Smiddy,Police Station and Station house had been built. The railway line ran parallel with the Main Road and it was here the village began to develop. After the war people from Sarclet and the surrounding district squatted in the empty Air Ministry Camp site houses at Tannach and in 1948 the first council houses were built along the roadside at Thrumster. Today there is no Smiddy railway or Police Station and the P.O. is a combination shop.There are now 56 council houses and 6 private bungalows Eight council tenants own their own homes.In 1960 modernisation began with the replacement of stone fireplaces, flag floors,cavity wall insulation and finally in 1982 the Caithness slates.
